column3: Shenzhen Nanotech Port Co., Shenzhen, China
column18: Algal media OECD 201
column25: The NPs in the media were autoclaved. Also experiments were performed in the dark. In this case toxicity value was 62.8 mg/l. MWCNTs were also washed additionally using HCl, no difefrence was found compared to original nanotubes.
column26: Nutrients were sorbed onto the CNTs but the in the presence of remaining nutrients, the algal cells still grew. Lipid peroxdation was obseved in the presence of CNTs. General ROS generation in the presence of CNTs and light was probably contributing to the toxicity. Shading of light contributed to toxicity. Aggregation of CNTs with algal cells, entrance to the cells.

column3:
Synthesized at EPFL Lausanne, Switzerland by chemical vapor deposition of acetylene over Fe2Co supported by CaCO3.
CNT are purified by HCl treatment to remove catalyst and a subsequent heat
treatment at 1000 °C to eliminate oxygen containing functional groups present on CNT surface
column8:
Fe and Co catalyst residues of 0.74 w%
and ~0.23 w%
column18: OECD algal test medium buffered with 1.00 mM HEPES, pH 7.00 ± 0.05
column25: The photosynthetic activity was not significantly affected by any tested particulate matter. Up to 95 ± 9% of all algal cells were agglomerated with CNT after 96 h
column26: The growth of the green algae was inhibited due to shading by CNT and the formation of algae-CNT agglomerates.
column28: Schwab, Fabienne; Bucheli, Thomas D.; Lukhele, Lungile P.; Magrez, Arnaud; Nowack, Bernd; Sigg, Laura; Knauer, Katja
column29: Are Carbon Nanotube Effects on Green Algae Caused by Shading and Agglomeration?

column18: Bold’s basal culture medium, pH 7.4
column25:
NP exposure led to a decreased in the number of cells, in a non-dose-dependent manner. After 96 hours, for MWCNT nanoparticles, a decrease of the photosynthetic activity at all concentrations was observed. SOD activity increased. The
ATP levels after contact with MWCNT decreased, and after 48 hours they were significantly lower than the levels in the control cells.
column26: NPs appear to affect algae growth and cause cell death by inducing oxidation, disturbing ATP production, decreasing photosynthetic activity and physical stress.
column28: Pereira, Michele M.; Mouton, Ludovic; Yepremian, Claude; Coute, Alain; Lo, Joanne; Marconcini, Jose M.; Ladeira, Luiz O.; Raposo, Nadia R. B.; Brandao, Humberto M.; Brayner, Roberta

column3: Synthesized by means of a floating catalytic chemical vapor deposition process using ferrocene and ethylene as the transition metal and carbon precursors, respectively. Purified by washing and filtering with isopropyl alcohol in a Millipore filtration system.
column18: Seine river water
column25:
A decrease in algal growth was only observed after 24 hours of exposure (100 μg/mL MWCNT). No photosynthetic
activity variation was observed after contact with 1 μg/mL MWCNT after 48 and 96 hours as well as after contact with 50 μg/mL after 24, 48 and 96 hours and after contact with 100 μg/mL between 24 and 72 hours. However, for 1 μg/mL MWCNT after
24 hours, 50 μg/mL MWCNT after 72 hours  and 100 μg/mL after 96 hours, the photosynthetic activities decreased significantly. An increase of SOD activity was observed after 24 hours. The
ATP levels after contact with MWCNT decreased, and after 48 hours they were significantly lower than the levels in the control cells.
column26: NPs appear to affect algae growth and cause cell death by inducing oxidation, disturbing ATP production, decreasing photosynthetic activity and physical stress.

column25: The presence of NP agglomerates of variable sizes trapped in mucus could be observed by light microscopy at the end of exposure period. In the digestive gland, a concentration-dependent decrease in lysosomal membrane stability and significant lysosomal lipofuscin accumulation only at higher concentrations were observed. Fullerenes stimulated catalase activity in the digestive gland but not in the gills. Fullerenes were ineffective to stimulate GST activity in the digestive gland but stimulated significantly GST activity in the gills.

column25: ZnO NPs enter the digestive system in the exposed daphnids. Whole mount samples showed the strongest signals throughout the intestinal epithelium, mainly along the brush border of the midgut region. Interestingly, this analysis evidenced also NP aggregates into the width of the intestinal epithelium, suggesting the digestive tract as one of the most crucial target and uptake site for NPs in D. magna. NPs inside microvilli were about 1/10 of those outside, with a preference towards the small sized ones, being in fact their median diameter relatively low (26.5 nm; 9.2e35 nm as I and II quartile).
column26: The smaller particles are quantitatively more toxic than the bigger ones. The toxic effects of ZnO NPs are independent from the dissolved Zinc ions available in the media. We cannot however exclude that once inside the cell, NP reactivity might increase by the release of a higher proportion of ions, thus causing additional effects and unbalancing the osmotic equilibrium of the cell.
column28: Santo, Nadia; Fascio, Umberto; Torres, Francesco; Guazzoni, Niccolo; Tremolada, Paolo; Bettinetti, Roberta; Mantecca, Paride; Bacchetta, Renato

Whole mount samples showed the strongest signals throughout the intestinal epithelium, mainly along the brush border of the midgut region. Interestingly, this analysis evidenced also NP aggregates into the width of the intestinal epithelium, suggesting the digestive tract as one of the most crucial target and uptake site for NPs in D. magna. NPs inside microvilli were about 1/10 of those outside, with a preference towards the small sized ones, being in fact their median diameter relatively low (26.5 nm; 9.2e35 nm as I and II quartile).
column26: The smaller particles are quantitatively more toxic than the bigger ones. The toxic effects of ZnO NPs are independent from the dissolved Zinc ions available in the media. We cannot however exclude that once inside the cell, NP reactivity might increase by the release of a higher proportion of ions, thus causing additional effects and unbalancing the osmotic equilibrium of the cell.

column29: Toxic effects and ultrastructural damages to Daphnia magna of two differently sized ZnO nanoparticles: Does size matter?

column25: Significant increases in MDA levels in hemolymph and soft tissues of ZnONP-treated snails (7 and 35 µg/ml) were observed. The results of the present study also showed a correlation between the enhancement of lipid peroxidation and a consequent depletion of GSH levels. The results of the present study showed significant inhibition in SOD activity after exposure to 7 µg/ml ZnONPs, whereas a significant increase was recorded after exposure to 35 µg/ml ZnONPs for 3 consecutive weeks in hemolymph and soft tissues of treated snails.

column3: Synthesized by the supercritical synthesis method. Metal precursor Ce(NO3)3 and ammonia water (pH control) was  mixed with supercritical water. CeO2 was collected by filter and spray dried
column18:
K-medium
(0.032M KCl, 0.051M NaCl)
column26:
The expression of most of the tested genes (metal response proteins mtl-1, cdr-1; xenobiotic metabolism enzyme gst-1; antioxidant enzymes sod-1, ctl-2; tumor suppressor and apoptosis
proteins cep-1, ape-1; yolk proteins vit-2, vit-6) was not significantly changed; increase in the expression of xenobitix metabolism enzyme cyp35a2 gene was the most pronounced.

column18: standard OECD algal medium, pH 7.4
column25:
Media containing >5 mg C/L NOM at low pH resulted in low toxicity; the highest toxicity was found at the highest pH of 8.4 in presence of only 2 mg C/L NOM and at pH 7.5 in absence of NOM; low NOM concentration at low pH and high NOM concentration (>5 mg C/L) at high pH caused an intermediate toxicity
48 h-EC20= -1626.4*(pH) + 109.45*(pH)² + 116.49*([NOM]) - 14.317*(pH)*([NOM]) + 6007.2
column28: Van Hoecke, Karen; De Schamphelaere, Karel A. C.; Van der Meeren, Paul; Smagghe, Guy; Janssen, Colin R.

column3:
0.5 M hexamethyleneter-amine (HMT) was mixed with 0.0375M Ce(NO3)3·6H2O at 75°C for 3 h. The particles
were washed 3 times by H2O and 3 times by EtOH, and dried at room temperature.
column18: solid nematode growth medium with Escherichia coli OP50
column25: The nematodes exposed to higher concentrations of nano-CeO2 had even shorter lifespan. nano-CeO2 exposure could significantly augment the generation and accumulation of lipofuscin in nematodes and the exposure significantly impaired the thermotolerance of C. elegans in a dose-dependent manner
column26: Aging was accelerated in C. elegans due to the intensified oxidative processes induced by nano-CeO2 exposure.
column27: nano-CeO2 could be uptaken by C. elegans  and found in the intestinal lumen

column25: Abnormal notochords and very weak heart beat were observed; furthermore, some of the flies had no or damaged eyes. The size of the yolk sack was approximately equal to the head, but the size of the head was smaller than the yolk sack in fish with damaged eyes. Specifically, when the concentration of nanosilver was high (20 ppt), the noted abnormalities increased.  The hatching rates were significantly decreased compared to the control.
column26: The catalase activities in the hatched flies were increased compared to the control. In the exposed groups, the Sel N2 gene expression decreased compared to the control group.

column25:
germination index (seed germination, %* root elongation, %/100)= 76.4 ± 17.8 %
The toxic effect of NPs-solvent (NaBH4) is more important than the NPs themselves.The differences observed between the NPs solutions and the NP-free solutions (solvent) can be correlated to the adsorption of solvent molecules at the NPs surface decreasing the effective concentration of those molecules. Thus, the observed toxic effect is less pronounced in the presence of NPs.

column26: The LC50 for AgNO3 was 15 µg/L. If toxicity was purely due to the dissolved Ag released by the Ag NPs (18–95 µg/L), ~100% mortality would be expexted. Thus, the toxicity produced by AgNO3 is more potent than that produced by dissolved Ag released by Ag NPs. As, similar concentrations of dissolved Ag were released from both treatments and mortality was significantly increased after sonication the increase in toxicity is due to a combination of the particulate Ag NPs and the dissolved Ag concentration released.

column3:
AgNO3 was reduced with sodium borohydride (NaBH4) in Milli-Q water. The molar ratio was 1:5 of AgNO3 to sodium citrate and 1:10 AgNO3 to NaBH4. The solution was stirred at
100rpm continuously at room temperature. Solutions were stirred for 3 hours and allowed to rest for at least 5 days prior to use.
column18: cell culture media Leibowitz 15
column22: cytotoxicity: inhibition of metabolic activity(fluorescent dye CFDA-AM)
column25: Neither the exposure to DOC nor Na3C6H5O7 with NaBH4 did cause significant cytotoxic effects (P > 0.05) on rainbow trout hepatocytes.
column26:
Neither size changes nor presence of DOC appeared to influence toxicity to a significant degree, suggesting that Ag nanoparticles may be toxic also under ecologically relevant exposure scenarios with natural agglomerates and association with DOC. No reactive oxygen radical (ROS) formation (fluorescent probe 2 ,7 -dichlorofluorescein diacetate) could be detected in this study. Although the exact toxic mechanisms were not determined, there was evidence that the toxic mode of
action could be connected to Ag binding to SH groups leading to dysfunction of target structures.
column28: Farkas, Julia; Christian, Paul; Urrea, Julian Alberto Gallego; Roos, Norbert; Hassellov, Martin; Tollefsen, Knut Erik; Thomas, Kevin V.
column29: Effects of silver and gold nanoparticles on rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss) hepatocytes

column3: [Ag(NH3)2]+ was reduced by D-maltose in alkaline media. Obtained aqueous NPs dispersion (C=108 mg Ag/L) was concentrated by dialysis (7 membranes, each 1 g of copolymer polyacrylate-polyalcohol) to a ﬁnal concentration of 270 mg Ag/L. BSA (final concentration of 0.01% w/w) was added to enhance the stability of the NPs. Mannitol was added at a ﬁnal concentration of 5% (w/w) and the mixture was homogenized and spray dryed. Obtained solid dispersion consisted of mannitol microparticles with an average size of 3 μm, in which silver NPs (2.5 mg Ag/g) were incorporated.
column10: Obtained solid dispersion consisted of mannitol microparticles with an average size of 3 μm
column18: standard culture medium (22 g of corn meal was added into 200 ml of distilled water and boiled for 90 minutes. 6.3 g of yeast and 12.5 g of sucrose and 40 ml mixture of 3.8 g of diluted agar were added into the boiled corn meal and the whole mixture was further boiled for 30 minutes. 10 ml of the disinfection solution, containing 12 g of benzoic acid and 2.5 g of sorbic acid diluted in 240 ml of denaturated ethanol, was added
column25:
Hatching of larvae and pupae was not affected at 20 mg/L, but 50% of hatching adults were not able to leave the pupae. 
Development time was prolonged from 14 days to 16 days at 40 mg/L. Silver concentrations equal to 60, 80, and 100 mg/L significantly influenced developmental stages in the phase of larvae development leading to a significant decrease in the number of larvae and pupae. Drosophila development cycle was not finished in such high silver concentrations and the individuals were unable to leave the pupae cases. At 100 mg/L concentration, 97% of larvae were dead, and no pupae were formed.
With increasing the silver concentration, the number of individuals with reduced pigmentation increased and the intensity of the reduced pigmentation also increased. Changes in eye pigmentation were not observed.
column28: Panacek, Ales; Prucek, Robert; Safarova, Dana; Dittrich, Milan; Richtrova, Jana; Benickova, Katerina; Zboril, Radek; Kvitek, Libor

column17: Saccharomyces cerevisiae S288C (α SUC2 mal mel gal2 CUP1)
column18: YPD (1% yeast extract, 2% polypeptone, 2% glucose)
column25:
191 genes were differentially expressed at 120 min. The largest number of genes affected by AgNPs and Ag-ions was found to be responsive to chemical stimulus, stress, and transport related cellular process. A noticeably large number of genes involved in cellular rescue and stress response were up-regulated by AgNPs, specifically at early growth stages at 120 min (46 genes) compared to 210 min (37 genes). 
19 most highly up-regulated genes were found as a result of common response to AgNPs through 120 and 210 min of exposure. 
CUP1-1 and CUP1-2 genes (encode the metallothionein protein responsible for binding copper and mediate high resistant to copper and cadmium) were consistently and strongly up-regulated (∼40–45-folds) followed by GSC2 (encodes for a subunit of 1,3-beta-glucan synthase) and YSR3 (membrane protein; 4.6-folds).
12 genes (PHO89, HSP12, HSP26, HOR7, GSC2, AMS1, CIT2, STR3, TMA10, HSP42, RTC3, and YBR085C-A genes) dominantly induced at 120 min, while their expression recovered over time, suggesting that AgNPs severely affected the genes involved in response to vacuolar phosphate transport, heat shock, hyperosmotic stress, cell wall proteins, and metabolism at the early growth stages.
TIS11, CCC2, TAF1, and FIT2 were moderately expressed at 120 min, but highly induced at 210 min of AgNP exposure. These four genes encode cell wall protein as well as transport proteins mainly the Cu2+ and iron transporters.
column26:
Early exposure of AgNPs caused metabolic imbalance and oxidative stress in yeast, which is consistent to the effect of AgNPs on high number of genes that take part in cell rescue and stress responses. The fact that highly reactive facets of AgNPs did not have ionic effect at initial growth stages (120 min) suggests that they mainly caused damage to membrane proteins and cell wall.
Prolonged exposure with AgNPs resulted in uncoupled function of copper and iron transporters, which under normal conditions involved in maintaining Cu2+ and iron
homeostasis. At 210 min, AgNPs appeared to have released ions in the medium, which resulted in the effect similar to that of Ag-ions.

column25: Factors as simple as the order of addition of the Ag-NPs and media constituents can have profound influences on the stability of Ag-NPs suspensions, the repeatability of the results and the sensitivity of the test organisms. The addition of a high concentration Ag-NP stock solution directly to a high ionic strength test media resulted in highly variable inhibition responses caused by a rapid aggregation and increase in Ag-NP size. Dilution of a high concentration Ag-NP stock solution to a concentration of 0.25– 1.0 ppm in deionized and distilled H2O, before the addition of the HEPES and (NH4)2SO4  resulted in a strong dose-dependent inhibition curve  increased sensitivity and a stable Ag-NP suspension with minimal increases in particle size.
column26: The released Ag+ is responsible for the observed Ag-NP toxicity and limits the likelihood of a nanoparticle-specific effect. Ammonia monooxygenase enzyme (AMO; oxidizes NH3 to hydroxylamine (NH2OH)) and hydroxylamine oxidoreductase enzyme (HAO; oxidizes hydroxylamine (NH2OH) to NO2-) specific oxygen uptake rates (SOUR) were both negatively impacted with AMO-SOURs being more sensitive to exposure than HAO-SOURs

column3: The leaves from the Piper betle L. (laboratory campus in Hyderabad, India) were plucked and washed with distilled water. The leaves were shade dried for 5 days at 28 ± 2 °C. 10 g of the leaves were boiled in 200mL of double-distilled deionized water for 5min before decanting to obtain broth. 190 mL of 10-3 M AgNO3 solution was added to 10 mL of leaf broth at 28 ± 2 °C and exposed to direct sunlight in Hyderabad, India (latitude 17 °N) in April 2010 from the time period between 10:00 a.m. and 1:00 p.m. for 5 min. Ag nanoparticle solution was puriﬁed using REMI ultramicrocentrifuge at 6000 rpm for 15 min followed by redispersion of the pellet of Ag NPs into 15mL of double-distilled water. The centrifuging and redispersing process was repeated for three times.

column25: Ag NPs significantly affected the community structure of marine biofilms. Nevertheless, all treated biofilms showed the presence of major bacterial groups, indicating that even at the highest concentrations studied the major taxonomic groups are not displaced.
column26: Exposure to Ag NPs reduced normal biofilm development and succession in these samples. In addition the presence of Ag NPs prevents settlement or colonization of new bacterial groups onto the biofilm, and biofilm succession is significantly modified by the presence of the NPs.
column27: The amount of Ag uptake by biofilms per unit of volume was 1.7 ± 0.4 and 18.3 ± 1.2 µg Ag/cm3 for 20 and 200 µg/L, and almost 10 times higher: 203.9 ± 31.3 µg Ag/cm3 for 2000 µg/L

column27: The amount of Ag uptake by biofilms per unit of volume was 1.7 ± 0.4 and 18.3 ± 1.2 µg Ag/cm3 for 20 and 200 µg/L, and almost 10 times higher: 203.9 ± 31.3 µg Ag/cm3 for 2000 µg/L
column28: Fabrega, Julia; Zhang, Rui; Renshaw, Joanna C.; Liu, Wen-Tso; Lead, Jamie R.
column29: Impact of silver nanoparticles on natural marine biofilm bacteria

column3: Stanford Materials C107Corp. (Aliso Viejo, CA), stock suspension in 0.25 mM sodium citrate solution
column11: Artificial seawater (21.19 g/L NaCl, 0.57 g/L KCl, 1.17 g/L CaCl2*2H2O, 3.99 g/L MgCl2*6H2O, 5.39 g/L MgSO4*7H2O, 0.15 g/L NaHCO3, pH 8, salinity 30 ppt, 4mg/L fulvic acids (1.83 g C/L))
column18: freshly collected seawater
column25: Ag NPs significantly affected the community structure of marine biofilms. Nevertheless, all treated biofilms showed the presence of major bacterial groups, indicating that even at the highest concentrations studied the major taxonomic groups are not displaced. Biofilm thickness was also reduced
column26: Exposure to Ag NPs reduced normal biofilm development and succession in these samples. In addition the presence of Ag NPs prevents settlement or colonization of new bacterial groups onto the biofilm, and biofilm succession is significantly modified by the presence of the NPs.
column27: The amount of Ag uptake by biofilms per unit of volume was 1.7 ± 0.4 and 18.3 ± 1.2 µg Ag/cm3 for 20 and 200 µg/L, and almost 10 times higher: 203.9 ± 31.3 µg Ag/cm3 for 2000 µg/L

0.1% Tween 20 and dispersed by sonication for 15 min.

column25: The levels of reduced glutathione (GSH) in earthworm were significantly higher than the control group, especially in the group exposed to 500 mg/kg. Activities of glutathione S-transferase (GST) in earthworm appeared to show a concentration-dependent increase as a function of dose. The activity of glutathione reductase (GR) was significantly lower than in the control group in both 100 and 500 mg/kg. Activities of acid phosphatase (AP)and Na+, K+-ATPase were significantly reduced at 500 mg/kg.
column26: Ag-NP with a concentration of 500 mg/kg led to the inhibition activity of Na+, K+-ATPase, suggesting that Ag-NP affect the membrane properties first and subsequently other biochemical activities.

column11:
moderately hard reconstituted water (96 mg/L NaHCO3, 60 mg/L CaSO4·2H2O,
60 mg/L MgSO4, 4 mg/L KCl; pH 7.6)
column18:
moderately hard reconstituted water (96 mg/L NaHCO3, 60 mg/L CaSO4·2H2O,
60 mg/L MgSO4, 4 mg/L KCl; pH 7.6, according to the US EPA)
column25: Preparation methods of Ag nanoparticle suspensions can affect toxicity based on total concentrations. In contrast, all of the suspensions prepared using different methods had a similar toxicity when expressed as dissolved concentrations, suggesting that the acute toxicity of Ag nanoparticles might originate from their dissolved fractions.
column26: No significant differences were observed in toxicity among suspensions filtered with different pore sizes. This indicates that the particles ranging from about 50 to 450 nm did not significantly contribute to the toxicity of nanoparticles. The acute toxicity of Ag nanoparticles can be accurately evaluated by focusing on the toxicity in terms of their dissolved concentration.

This indicates that the particles ranging from about 50 to 450 nm did not significantly contribute to the toxicity of nanoparticles. The acute toxicity of Ag nanoparticles can be accurately evaluated by focusing on the toxicity in terms of their dissolved concentration.
column28: Jo, Hun Je; Choi, Jae Woo; Lee, Sang Hyup; Hong, Seok Won
column29: Acute toxicity of Ag and CuO nanoparticle suspensions against Daphnia magna: The importance of their dissolved fraction varying with preparation methods

column3:
NM-300K from the OECD Sponsorship
Program (colloidal dispersion)
column5: 4% (w/w) each of polyoxy-ethylene glycerol trioleate and polyoxyethylene sorbitan monolaurate (Tween-20)
column18: 625g RefeSol 01A,a loamy, medium-acidic, and lightly humic sand (pH 5.67; Corg 0.93%, sand 71%, silt 24%, clay 5%), 55% WHC(max) 40g cow dung (air dried, ground, and moistened before application)
column25:
At the beginning of the test, the earthworms tried to escape from the 120 and 200 mg/kg soil test vessels. However, after 24 h, all earthworms went back into the soil, although some tried to stay in the food that had been spread over the top of the soil.
The increase in biomass showed a statistically significant increase over the negative controls.
column26: Toxicity caused by Ag-NPs is closely related to the content of released Ag+ measured in the soil pore water.
column27: The concentrations of Ag in earthworms exposed to NM-300K ranged from 7.0 mg/kg worm at 15 mg/kg soil to 11.3 mg/kg worm at 120 mg/kg soil. all calculated BAF values were below 1.0. There was a concentration-dependent reduction in the bioaccumulation factors (BAFs), and Ag-NPs yielded higher BAFs than Ag nitrate from concentrations of 30 mg/kg soil up to 200 mg/kg soil.
column28: Schlich, Karsten; Klawonn, Thorsten; Terytze, Konstantin; Hund-Rinke, Kerstin
column29: Effects of silver nanoparticles and silver nitrate in the earthworm reproduction test

column27: Those specimens exposed to AgNPs accumulate a significantly higher amount of Ag in their bodies than those exposed to AgNO3. The amounts accumulated by different individuals varies, some individuals tend to absorb more, or else have more problems to excrete Ag. Overall, Ag body burden values obtained for both populations (deceased and survivors) are very similar (mean standard deviation: 71±39 mg/g Ag for survivors; 75±42 mg/g Ag for deceased specimens).

column3: PVP (234 mg) was dissolved in 40 mL water followed by the addition of AgNO3 (141 mg, 0.83 mmol). A solution of NaBH4 (312 mg, 8.3 mmol) in 10 ml water was slowly added to the polymer solution. After stirring overnight in an open vessel a clear, dark brown solution of nanoparticles was obtained. The particles were purified by dialysis against water and freezedried.

column18: dechlorinated tap water
column25: No significant increase in CuZnSOD (superoxide dismutase) mRNA expression level was observed, MnSOD expression level was down-regulated, CAT (catalase) mRNA expression was significantly increased, the expression of PHGPx1 (phospholipid hydroperoxide glutathione peroxidase 1) mRNA increased concentration-dependantly by AgNP exposure. There was a steady increase in the expression of TrXR1 (thioredoxin reductase 1) with highest expression being observed after exposure to 1 mg/L of AgNPs. The mRNA expression levels of GSTd3, GSTs4 and GSTe1 (glutathione S-transferases) were significantly increased to varying levels upon exposure to all concentrations of AgNPs.
column26: AgNPs leads to excess oxidative stress in C. riparius. There might be interactions of AgNPs with sub cellular structures such as mitochondria, leading to excess oxidative stress, which reduces the mRNA expression of MnSOD. In order to counteract the excess formation of H2O2 by the action of different SODs by conversion of superoxide radicals, formed as a result of AgNPs exposure, might have resulted in the up-regulation of CAT mRNA. PHGPx1 may also participate in the protection against oxidative stress caused by exposure to AgNPs. TrxR1 plays an important role in protection against oxidative stress caused by AgNPs.
column28: Nair, Prakash M. Gopalakrishnan; Park, Sun Young; Choi, Jinhee
column29: Evaluation of the effect of silver nanoparticles and silver ions using stress responsive gene expression in Chironomus riparius

column18: Ag spiked sediment (Isefjorden, Denmark 55°40' N, 11°47' E) and seawater
column25: Clams buried rapidly in the first 30 min, no avoidance behavior of clams in Ag-spiked sediment was observed.
column27: The specific body burden of Ag was significantly lower in the soft tissue of clams in micrometer-Ag relative to aqueous Ag and Ag ENPs-20.
column28: Dai, Lina; Syberg, Kristian; Banta, Gary T.; Selck, Henriette; Forbes, Valery E.
column29: Effects, Uptake, and Depuration Kinetics of Silver Oxide and Copper Oxide Nanoparticles in a Marine Deposit Feeder, Macoma balthica

column29: Effects, Uptake, and Depuration Kinetics of Silver Oxide and Copper Oxide Nanoparticles in a Marine Deposit Feeder, Macoma balthica

affects the longevity, and the toxicity is due to particles
rather than dissolved ions. AgNPs induce JNK-mediated cellular stress responses.

column29: Development of biomarker for detecting silver nanoparticles exposure using a GAL4 enhancer trap screening in Drosophila

column3: Sigma-Aldrich Chemical, St. Louis,MO; filtered through 100 nm cellulose membrane
column18: k-media (0.032 M KCl, 0.051 M NaCl)
column25: Internal AgNPs always appeared as aggregates and were mainly distributed around the uterine area. The expression of four genes (nonannotated gene M162.5, metallothionein mtl-2, superoxide dismutase sod-3, and abnormal dauer formation proteindaf-12) was upregulated by AgNPs exposure. The increased expression of mtl-2 and sod-3 occurred in a AgNPs concentration dependent manner.
column26: AgNPs were slightly more toxic than Ag ions in terms of reproduction potential, and also it appeared that different mechanisms exerted toxicity with AgNPs and with Ag ions, as stress-related gene expression patterns were different between these two groups. Increased sod-3 gene expression in exposed worms was considered to confirm the involvement of oxidative stress in AgNPs-induced toxicity in this test system. Increased daf-12 expression observed here suggested that AgNPs exposure may have acted as an environmental stressor that regulated C. elegans dauer formation.

column3: Synthesized using the citrate reduction method (18 mg of AgNO3 in 100 ml of deionized water was heated under magnetic stirring until boiling. Then 7 ml of 1% of sodium citrate solution in water was quickly added. The heating was continued until color changed to dark brown green. The solution was removed from heating and stirred until it has cooled to room temperature). NPs were further centrifuged to obtain spherical geometry.
column11:
Fresh river water (Ross Barnett Reservoir, Ridgeland, Mississippi), pH 6.83–6.87,
TOC 17–19 mg/L, TSS 22–23 mg/L, BOD 13–15 mg/L, COD 40–41 mg/L, nitrates <1.0 mg/L, surfactants 2.6–2.8 D.B.S.

column3:
Sigma–Aldrich Chemical (St. Louis, MO,
USA), filtered through a cellulose membrane (pore size 100 nm)
column18: dechlorinated tap water and acid washed sand
column26: AgNPs may provoke genotoxicity in C. riparius. The expression level of the ribosomal protein gene CrL15 was found to be down-regulated as a result of AgNPs exposure, which in turn may affect the ribosome assembly and synthesis of other proteins. The CrGnRH1 gene was found to be up-regulated on exposure to AgNPs, the increased expression of this gene may be involved in the altered reproduction potential after treatment with AgNPs. The up-regulation of the CrBR2.2 gene upon treatment with AgNPs may be due to its protective role towards the adverse effects of AgNPs in C. riparius, which may be useful as a molecular indicator for AgNPs toxicity.

column25:
The diversity of substrate utilization was reduced to 16%. Ag NP treatment reduced the recovery of 16S sequences an average of 44% (range: 13–70%) assigned to 5/6 of the major orders (Solirubrobacterales, Actinomycetales, Rhizobiales, Acidobacteriales and Clostridiales). A relative increase (4% vs. 9%) in the proportion of recovered sequences was found after treatment only in the Bacillales.
MCT25 value is in the top 75%;thus Ag NPs are potentially highly toxic.

Large amounts of a dark material were found in the gut tract, in some cases the incestion of the particles caused Daphnia to sink to the bottom of the beakers.  26.3 to 31%
of the live Daphnia exhibited abnormal swimming. In 
0.1 mg/L, most frequent was erratic swimming, yet in the higher concentrations the Daphnids migrated to the bottom or the surface.

column25: Physa growth rates were reduced at higher AgNP concentrations. When stressed by environmentally relevant AgNP  concentrations (0.01 µg/l), Physa reproduction was reduced  as indicated by fewer eggmasses and fewer total eggs. Snails exhibited potential stress behaviors such as faster movement rates and near-surface habitat use. Silver nanoparticle changes in Physa movement or antipredator behaviors may negatively affect their survival directly by increasing the time that they may be in predatory danger.
column28: Bernot, Randall J.; Brandenburg, Michael

column3: RAS GmbH (Regensburg, Germany; nanosilver aqueous dispersion, containing 10% silver, 7% ammonium nitrate, 8% emulsifier, and 75% de-ionised water
column18: M4 medium without EDTA The medium was changed twice a week and daphnids were fed  with green algae S. Acutus (0.2 mg C per daphnid per day)
column25: In multi-generation experiments generations 0 to 3 showed mortality levels below 20% and generation 4 was with a mortality of 30.0% at 10 µg Ag/L. Exposure to nanosilver significantly impaired the reproductive output of D. magna. Reproduction of generation F3’ and F4’ was significantly impaired during the recovery period and remained in the range of the 10 mg Ag/L treatment group of the multi-generation experiment.
column28: Voelker, Carolin; Boedicker, Cathinka; Daubenthaler, Jan; Oetken, Matthias; Oehlmann, Joerg
column29: Comparative Toxicity Assessment of Nanosilver on Three Daphnia Species in Acute, Chronic and Multi-Generation Experiments

column3: RAS GmbH (Regensburg, Germany; nanosilver aqueous dispersion, containing 10% silver, 7% ammonium nitrate, 8% emulsifier, and 75% de-ionised water
column18: M4 medium without EDTA The medium was changed twice a week and daphnids were fed  with green algae S. Acutus (0.2 mg C per daphnid per day)
column25: In multi-generation experiments generation 0 showed mortality between 0 and 30% at lower concentrations and 58.3% at 5 µg Ag/L; in gen. 1 mortality did not exceed 25%; in gen. 3 morality increased with concentrations (58.3% at 1.25 µg Ag/L, 66.7% at 5 µg Ag/L); in gen. 3&4 mortality did not exceed 25%. The reproductive output of D. pulex was not affected by low concentrations of nanosilver.
column28: Voelker, Carolin; Boedicker, Cathinka; Daubenthaler, Jan; Oetken, Matthias; Oehlmann, Joerg
column29: Comparative Toxicity Assessment of Nanosilver on Three Daphnia Species in Acute, Chronic and Multi-Generation Experiments

column3: RAS GmbH (Regensburg, Germany; nanosilver aqueous dispersion, containing 10% silver, 7% ammonium nitrate, 8% emulsifier, and 75% de-ionised water
column18: M4 medium without EDTA The medium was changed twice a week and daphnids were fed  with green algae S. Acutus (0.2 mg C per daphnid per day)
column25: In multi-generation experiments generation 0 mortality reached to 83.3% at 10 µg Ag/L, in gen. 1 to 6.70% and in gen. 2 to 86.7% and population became extinct. In gen. 3-4 no mortality occured in concentrations up to 1.25 µg Ag/L. Neonate numbers of D. galeata were generally lower compared to the other tested species (D. magna, D. pulex).

column25: The yolk sac membrane of the embryo became damaged, leading to the leakage of yolk and subsequently mortality. The surface of the blastoderm became rough and epiboly was delayed in comparison with control embryos. Embryos that survived the exposure to silver at high exposure concentrations subsequently had morphological abnormalities including bent tails, small head and a reduced yolk sac size. Significant induction of Mt2 (3.9 fold) was detected in the YSL especially at the posterior extension.
column26: The amount of silver ions in solution does not explain all of the toxicity observed. However; the silver particles settle on the embryo surface and therefore the local concentration of dissolved Ag ions is likely to be higher-

column18:
Bacterial growth media: Luria-Bertani media supplemented
with 5% fetal bovine serum and 25 μg/mL of kanamycin
column25: Within the series of citrate-coated Ag nanomaterials, increasing the size significantly decreased their toxicity toward Escherichia coli bacteria. Although there are some common pathways involved in how bacteria respond to silver stress, there are other pathways that appear to correlate with nanoparticlerelated stress. Reactive oxygen production and impairment of flagellar activity were observed for a broad range of silver species. By contrast, effects on cell outer surface lipopolysaccharides appear to be nanoparticle-specific.
column26: Although Ag NPs toxicity is on a large scale mediated by dissolved Ag ions, the way in which the particles interact with bacterial cells and some of the pathways involved in the toxicity of the particles are highly dependent on nanoparticle physicochemical properties.
column28: Ivask, Angela; ElBadawy, Amro; Kaweeteerawat, Chitrada; Boren, David; Fischer, Heidi; Ji, Zhaoxia; Chang, Chong Hyun; Liu, Rong; Tolaymat, Thabet; Telesca, Donatello; Zink, Jeffrey I.; Cohen, Yoram; Holden, Patricia Ann; Godwin, Hilary A.

column3:
For the synthesis of Ag-PVP, solutions of 9.4*10^-3 M AgNO3 (50 mL), 15.8*10^-3 M NaBH4 (150 mL), and 0.75% PVP (PVP 40, Mw = 40 000, 50 mL) were prepared. The three solutions were
delivered with volume ratios of 1 AgNO3/1 PVP/3 NaBH4 to an empty beaker using a multichannel peristaltic pump.The beaker was stirred vigorously using a stir bar on a stir plate. After the total volume of the three solutions was delivered to the beaker, the pH of the resulting nanoparticle
suspension was adjusted to 4.0 using a 5% HNO3 solution.
column18:
Bacterial growth media: Luria-Bertani media supplemented
with 5% fetal bovine serum and 25 μg/mL of kanamycin
column25: The ability of positively charged Ag NPs to tightly interact with bacterial surface results in high concentrations of bioavailable Ag ions from these particles. Positively charged particles also interfere with the normal function of the bacterial electron transport chain and are responsible for ROS formation at the cell membrane. Although there are some common pathways involved in how bacteria respond to silver stress, there are other pathways that appear to correlate with nanoparticlerelated stress. Reactive oxygen production and impairment of flagellar activity were observed for a broad range of silver species. By contrast, effects on cell outer surface lipopolysaccharides appear to be nanoparticle-specific.
column26: Although Ag NPs toxicity is on a large scale mediated by dissolved Ag ions, the way in which the particles interact with bacterial cells and some of the pathways involved in the toxicity of the particles are highly dependent on nanoparticle physicochemical properties.

column3:
For the synthesis of Ag-PVP, solutions of 9.4*10^-3 M AgNO3 (50 mL), 15.8*10^-3 M NaBH4 (150 mL), and 0.75% PVP (PVP 40, Mw = 40 000, 50 mL) were prepared. The three solutions were
delivered with volume ratios of 1 AgNO3/1 PVP/3 NaBH4 to an empty beaker using a multichannel peristaltic pump.The beaker was stirred vigorously using a stir bar on a stir plate. After the total volume of the three solutions was delivered to the beaker, the pH of the resulting nanoparticle
suspension was adjusted to 4.0 using a 5% HNO3 solution.
column18:
Bacterial growth media: Luria-Bertani media supplemented
with 5% fetal bovine serum and 25 μg/mL of kanamycin
column25: The ability of positively charged Ag NPs to tightly interact with bacterial surface results in high concentrations of bioavailable Ag ions from these particles. Positively charged particles also interfere with the normal function of the bacterial electron transport chain and are responsible for ROS formation at the cell membrane. Although there are some common pathways involved in how bacteria respond to silver stress, there are other pathways that appear to correlate with nanoparticlerelated stress. Reactive oxygen production and impairment of flagellar activity were observed for a broad range of silver species. By contrast, effects on cell outer surface lipopolysaccharides appear to be nanoparticle-specific.
column26: Although Ag NPs toxicity is on a large scale mediated by dissolved Ag ions, the way in which the particles interact with bacterial cells and some of the pathways involved in the toxicity of the particles are highly dependent on nanoparticle physicochemical properties.

column3: For the synthesis of BPEI-Ag, 0.085 g of N-(2-hydroxyethyl)- piperazine-N'-2-ethanesulfonic acid (HEPES) was dissolved in a 100 mL solution of 9.4*10^-3 M AgNO3. The pH of the mixture (AgNO3/HEPES) was adjusted to a pH of 6.5 using 1% branched polyethyleneimine solution (BPEI, Mw = 1.20 kg/mol). The mixture was exposed for 80 min to UV irradiation using a standard lowpressure mercury arc lamp.

column25: Chlorophyll a, chlorophyll b, carotenoid and pheophytin contents were not affected. Protein content in leaves was not significantly modified neither. Similarly, TBARS content was unchanged.
column27: Ag agglomerates (mean diameter of 2–3 µm) were detected all over the surface of leaves, including stomata. Ag was also detected inside the leaf tissues: in the parenchyma, Ag hot spots of about 2 µm in diameter were observed either inside cells or associated to the cell walls. Ag agglomerates were also observed between the guard cells and in the sub-stomatal chamber.

through a 0.22 µm pore size filter.

column25: The yolk sac was not completely absorbed by 10% and 17% embryos treated with 100 μg/L and 125 μg/L of AgNP, respectively and the presence of pericardial edema was observed in one of the embryos from the concentration of 125 μg/L. Clumps of brownish flakes were detected inside the chorionic fluid of the embryos treated with AgNP, which suggests an inherent effect caused by nanoparticles as there are no similar evidences in AgNO3 exposures. At 51.57 μg/L of AgNP, 50% of the embryos had these brown flakes in the chorion.

column11: filtered lake water from VIT lake, Vellore, India: conductance: 4.5±0.17 mS/cm; pH: 7.7±0.2; dissolved oxygen (DO): 7.4±0.49 mg/L; total dissolved solids (TDS): 820±80 mg/L; total organic carbon (TOC): 15 mg/C/L
column18: filtered lake water from VIT lake, Vellore, India: conductance: 4.5±0.17 mS/cm; pH: 7.7±0.2; dissolved oxygen (DO): 7.4±0.49 mg/L; total dissolved solids (TDS): 820±80 mg/L; total organic carbon (TOC): 15 mg/C/L
column25: Incubation of consortium in AgNPs at 1 µg/mL concentrations resulted in the formation of flake like cell aggregates. After 6 h of interaction practically all the cells were assembled into aggregates, and single cells were very few in numbers. The AgNPs were observed to be adsorbed on the cell surface of the bacterial cell wall in the treated samples. The morphology of the cells in the bacterial consortium was changed from regular shape to irregular, distorted shape, formation of small vacuole-like structures could be noted giving a patchy appearance to cells.
column26: No involvement of ion leaching from the AgNPs was observed at low concentration levels (≤1 ppm) proving that the observed toxicity was probably due to enhanced colloidal stability of AgNPs in the experimental medium.
column28: Kumar, Deepak; Kumari, Jyoti; Pakrashi, Sunandan; Dalai, Swayamprava; Raichur, Ashok M.; Sastry, T. P.; Mandal, A. B.; Chandrasekaran, N.; Mukherjee, Amitava
column29: Qualitative toxicity assessment of silver nanoparticles on the fresh water bacterial isolates and consortium at low level of exposure concentration

The AgNPs were observed to be adsorbed on the cell surface of the bacterial cell wall in the treated samples. The morphology of the cells in the bacterial consortium was changed from regular shape to irregular, distorted shape, formation of small vacuole-like structures could be noted giving a patchy appearance to cells.
column26: No involvement of ion leaching from the AgNPs was observed at low concentration levels (≤1 ppm) proving that the observed toxicity was probably due to enhanced colloidal stability of AgNPs in the experimental medium.

The results show that TiO2 nanoparticles had a significantly stronger adsorption
capacity for Cd than SP. The presence of SP did not have significant influence on the accumulation of Cd in carp during the 25 d of
exposure. However, the presence of TiO2 nanoparticles greatly enhanced the accumulation of Cd in carp. After 25 d of exposure Cd concentration
in carp increased by 146%, and the value was 22.3 and 9.07 lg/g, respectively. And there is a positive correlation between Cd
and TiO2 concentration. Considerable Cd and TiO2 accumulated in viscera and gills of the fish.

column18: artificial sea water
column22: lysosomal membrane stability of mussel hemocytes
column25:
None of the NP tested significantly
affected lysosomal membrane stability, indicating the lack of a major toxic effect. However, all NP suspensions induced a concentration-dependent lysozyme release, extracellular oxyradical and nitric oxide (NO) production, to a different extent and with different time courses depending on the concentration and the NP type. The inflammatory effects of NPs were mediated by rapid activation of the stress-activated p38 MAPK.

Lemna minor cells accumulated more ROS when the plant was exposed to TiO2 NPs than when exposed to the same concentration of bulk TiO2. The plant cells increased antioxidant
defense-enzyme (POD, SOD, and CAT) activity to eliminate the accumulated ROS in plant cells when the TiO2
NP concentration was lower than 200 mg/L in the culture media. The SOD activity decreased when the TiO2 NP concentration was higher than 200 mg/L, and the plant cell encountered serious damage from 500 mg/L TiO2 NP concentration in the culture media.

column18:
Sandy loam soil with a pH of 5.8, total organic carbon 1.36%, clay 11.6%, silt 21.4%, and sand 64.7% (from Askov experimental station, Aarhus University, Faculty of Agricultural Sciences,
Denmark, batch no. 2-031207); The worms were fed weekly with 5 g dried cow-dung, pH of 8.5, from non-medicated animals.
column25: After the exposure the gain in wet weight was 169 ± 64.0% (no increment/loss= 0%; increment in wet weight in case of the control= 100%). TiO2-NP caused a significantly reduced reproductive success.
column28: Heckmann, Lars-Henrik; Hovgaard, Mads B.; Sutherland, Duncan S.; Autrup, Herman; Besenbacher, Flemming; Scott-Fordsmand, Janeck J.
column29: Limit-test toxicity screening of selected inorganic nanoparticles to the earthworm Eisenia fetida

column18: ISO test medium
column25:
All animals completed the first molting within 36 h without any substantial
differences between animals exposed to  nTiO2 and the controls. The second molting occurred in 100% of control animals between 66 and 78 h after
the start of the test, while animals exposed to nTiO2 showed a delay in molting and, most importantly, a significantly lower molting success of only 10%.
column26:
nTiO2 has a negative impact on the
molting and development of D. magna, which is likely to be connected to biological surface coating as a general pathway of physical NP toxicity.
column27: NP showed a high tendency to bind to organic surfaces, resulting in a steadily growing layer of TiO2 on daphnids within the 96-h exposure period. The coating was visible within the first 24 h of exposure and completely disappeared with the first molting. Biological surface coating reoccurred within 1 h after the first molting and continued steadily during the 96-h exposure period.
column28: Dabrunz, Andre; Duester, Lars; Prasse, Carsten; Seitz, Frank; Rosenfeldt, Ricki; Schilde, Carsten; Schaumann, Gabriele E.; Schulz, Ralf
column29: Biological Surface Coating and Molting Inhibition as Mechanisms of TiO2 Nanoparticle Toxicity in Daphnia magna

column27: NP showed a high tendency to bind to organic surfaces, resulting in a steadily growing layer of TiO2 on daphnids within the 96-h exposure period. The coating was visible within the first 24 h of exposure and completely disappeared with the first molting. Biological surface coating reoccurred within 1 h after the first molting and continued steadily during the 96-h exposure period.

column25:
All animals completed the first molting within 36 h without any substantial
differences between animals exposed to  nTiO2 and the controls. The second molting occurred in 100% of control animals between 66 and 78 h after
the start of the test, while animals exposed to nTiO2 showed a delay in molting and, most importantly, a significantly lower molting success of only 10%.

After 4 h of continuous stirring, the formed light green color change indicated the formation of TiO2 NPs.

column18: Compost; day/night relative humidity 49/74%. NPs were deposited as droplets on the leaf surface.
column25: Chlorophyll a, chlorophyll b, carotenoid and pheophytin concentrations were not affected by TiO2-NP exposure. Similarly, TBARS remained unchanged.
column27: Lettuce leaves showed Ti-containing particles on their surface and close to stomatal openings. These particles were also found inside the sub-stomatal chamber. Pristine NPs were shown to be transferred insidethe leaf tissue, and accumulated both in the extracellular and intracellular compartments. Both stomatal and cuticular pathways might be involved in the transfer. The crystalline form of NPs was not modified upon bioaccumulation.

column18: seawater, salinity 33.6 parts per thousand, conductivity  54.9 mS/cm
column25:
The gene for heatshock protein 70 (HSP70) was upregulated by the treatment at time point 48 h compared to control, but not at 7 d or 17 d. Addition of 0.1 mg/L of nano-TiO2 increased
expression of HSP70 5-fold, while addition of 10 mg/L increased expression of HSP70 19 times.
column27: After 17 d of exposure to 0.1 mg/L and 10 mg/L of nano-TiO2, the bioconcentration factors were 62 and 238 (for the 0.1 mg/L group) and 2 and 594 (for the 10 mg/L group) for coral tissue and the posterior mixture, respectively. Concentrations detected in the posterior mixture of burrowing sponges, fungi, and bacteria were significantly higher than the concentrations from coral tissue for each experimental group

column18:
Osterhout's medium (0.01% NaCl, 0.0008% MgCl2, 0.0004% MgSO4, 0.0002% KCl, 0.0001% CaCl2 in
MilliQ water) pH 6.6, conductivity 170 μS/cm
column20: 25 °C, incubated on a microplate shaker, 300 rpm
column25: 24 h exposure to the EC50 concentration of nCuO caused a significant increase in the relative amount of two saturated fatty acids (stearic and palmitic acid; C18:0 and C16:0), and a decrease in the proportions of two major unsaturated fatty acids (γ-linolenic and linoleic acid; C18:3 and C18:2). The EC20 and EC50 concentrations of both, nano and bulk CuO, induced about four times higher levels of TBARS than in the control culture. nCuO generated significantly higher levels of ROS compared to bCuO and CuSO4
column26: Lipid peroxidation per se is not the main mechanism of toxicity for the tested copper compounds. Toxic effect of nCuO in T. thermophila is not solely caused by the dissolved fraction of the NPs, but rather displays a distinctive toxicity pattern. One of the key factors in the adaptation mechanism to nCuO could be the regulation of specific desaturase activity, thereby lowering membrane fluidity.
column28: Mortimer, Monika; Kasemets, Kaja; Vodovnik, Masa; Marinsek-Logar, Romana; Kahru, Anne
column29: Exposure to CuO Nanoparticles Changes the Fatty Acid Composition of Protozoa Tetrahymena thermophila

column18: stream water (silica 9.6 ± 2 mg/L, Na+ 4.1 ± 0.4 mg/L, Ca2+ 1.3 ± 0.3 mg/L, K+ 0.6 ± 0.1 mg/L, HCO3- 8.0 ± 0.8 mg/L, Cl-  4.2 ± 0.4 mg/L, and SO4- 1.0 ± 0.2 mg/L. pH 5.8 ± 0.2
column25: Leaf consumption rate was affected by both nanoparticle concentration and type of exposure. The growth rate of the invertebrate shredder was affected by the concentration of nanoCuO, regardless the type of exposure, i.e. via water or pre-contaminated food.
column26: The leached ionic copper may have greatly contributed to the toxicity of nanoCuO at lethal or sublethal concentrations.
column27: After 10 d of exposure via stream water to nanoCuO, a substantial contamination of leaves occurred concomitantly with accumulation and adsorption of Cu to larval body. The adsorbed Cu was higher on leaves, intermediate on the larval case and lower on the larval body.

column27: The bioaccumulation increases with the increase of NP concentration and reaches a maximum capacity at 20 mg/L of nano-Fe2O3(m) or more.  Ingestion of NPs is the main route of nano-Fe2O3(m) bioaccumulation. The highest bioaccumulation was found at a pH of 7–8. Both low pH and high pH could have decreased the amount of accumulation. Under natural pH (7.8) conditions of the medium, the NPs were positively charged, which were helpful for NP uptake by C. dubia.

column25: Soluble Fe ions from nano-Fe2O3 (m) have no toxicity to C. dubia. Nano-Fe2O3 (m) made As(V) much more toxic, and synergistic effects between As(V) and nano-Fe2O3 (m) were present.
column27: The maximum NP uptake in C. dubia was achieved at 20 mg/L NP concentration. The maximum uptake was 0.1mg per daphnia at 24 h and 0.06mg per daphnia at 48 h. These maximal values remained stable even after the further increase in particle concentration. It was suspected that the settling of NPs after 24 h resulted in fewer NPs in the suspension, which led to the reduced exposure of nano-Fe2O3 (m) to C. dubia, and that the previously ingested NPs were gradually released.

column25:
Suspended nFe3O4 gradually aggregated within 2 h, with barely detectable ionic species (<0.2 mg/L). Exposure to nFe3O4 for 1 to 14 days dose and
time-dependently increased CAT and GR activities and ROS levels but decreased SOD activity. After 7-day recovery in ERM, the alteration in antioxidant balance and ROS production with nFe3O4 was ameliorated or completely recovered to control levels.
column27:
Bioconcentrartion in larvae after 3 days of exposure: 0 mg/L - iron conc. in larvae 0.59 ± 0.18; 25mg/L - 6.13 ± 0.04 and Bioconcentration factor (BCF, L/g-bw) = iron conc. in larvae/measured total iron (TI) concentration of the dosing solution was 0,22; 50mg/L - 5.68 ± 0.84 and BCF=0,14; 100mg/L - 3.56 ± 0.89 and BCF=0,04. Iron accumulated in the gastrointestinal (GI) tract or gills of treated groups. However,  larval morphologic features were not significantly changed with a shorter period of nFe3O4 (100 mg/L, 3 day exposure) containing
solution.

column3: Purchased from Nanjing High Technology NANO CO., Ltd. (Nanjing, China).
column18: Zebrafish culture medium (64.75 mg/L NaHCO3, 5.75 mg/L KCl, 123.25 mg/L MgSO·7H2O, and 294 mg/L CaCl2·2H2O) prepared according to ISO (Geneva, Switzerland) standard 7346-3:1996.
column25: The nFe2O3-treated embryos showed a dose-dependent effect on the hatching rates.
column26: The addition of nFe2O3 to the culture medium resulted in the formation of aggregates that settled out of the water column very quickly. This aggregation and sedimentation phenomenon of nFe2O3 is similar to other NPs. These findings revealed that aggregates or agglomerates of NPs are likely to settle out of solution and sink into sediments rather than remain in suspension. Thus, benthic organisms living in sediments or at the bottom of aquatic environments could be potential targets of NPs released into the environment.

column25: At a concentration of >50 mg/L some affected embryos were unable to hatch and eventually died. Malformation was more serious in the embryos and larvae exposed to 100 mg/L nFe2O3, although no significant difference was found from those in the 50-mg/L treatment group.
